column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album
column16: Photo album created by Corporal John L. Wallace during his military training at Fort McCoy in Wisconsin.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, front cover
column16: Cover of album includes the text "Photographs" and "Camp McCoy, Wisc."  The Great Seal, which includes a bald eagle and the text "E. Pluribus Unum" is present.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 1
column16: This page features "Autographs of my friends."  A date, signature, address, and message is included for each contributor. The messages date from 1950-1951 and include well wishes like "Be cool, my man."

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 2
column16: A second page of "Autographs of my friends." A date, signature, address, and message is included for each contributor. The messages date from 1951-1952 and include well wishes like "We will be home again some day."

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 3
column16: A third blank page of "Autographs of my friends."

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 4
column16: Page includes five posed photographs.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 5
column16: Page includes one photograph of two Black soldiers with cigars in an office space.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 6
column16: Page includes one photograph of three Black men in suits posing together.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 7
column16: Page includes one photograph of a Black soldier standing in the snow under a tree.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 8
column16: Page includes three photographs of Black soldiers and buildings. One photograph depicts a jeep with "Military Police" written across its front.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 9
column16: Page includes four photographs of Black soldiers and military vehicles.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 10
column16: Page includes three photographs of Black soldiers and buildings.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 11
column16: Page includes two photographs of Black soldiers on military vehicle phones.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 12
column16: Page includes two photographs of Black soldiers in front of barracks.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 13
column16: Page includes three photographs of Black soldiers.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 14
column16: Page includes three photographs of Black soldiers.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 15
column16: Page includes two photographs of Black soldiers.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 16
column16: Page includes three photographs of Black soldiers near barracks and the mess hall.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 17
column16: Page includes three photographs of Black soldiers. One photo shows two people getting food while another has a soldier posing in front of a jeep.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 18
column16: Page includes four photographs. The upper two photographs are of the exterior of barracks. The photo in the lower left shows a soldier standing inside a barrack next to two cots. The lower right photo depicts two men getting food in the cafeteria.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 19
column16: Page includes two photographs of Black soldiers posing.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 20
column16: Page includes six photographs of Black women posing outside. Five of the six photos depict a single individual while the one on the lower right is a group shot with three women and one man.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 21
column16: Page includes three photographs of Black men and women posing outside.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 22
column16: Page includes two photographs of the same Black woman posing in front of a painted backdrop of a domestic exterior with a gate.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 23
column16: Page includes two photographs of named individuals. The photo on the left captures a group of soliders and includes inscriptions indicating the name and origin of each individual. The names and origins listed are: James Stewart (Fresn Cal.), Joe Vachon (Rumford Maine), Ollie Bunn (Wilson N.C.) Percy Johnston (??), Sabeme Bey (Toledo O.) Cris Gwisham (Toledo O.), Lonnie Lewis (Chicago Ill.) and Fred Bonaparte (Phila. Pa.). Also inscribed is "brks 6217" (barracks 6217). Wallace has also included arrows to his bunk and the war hawks field baseball park. The photo on the right includes the inscription "My dad" and depicts a Black man in a vest in front of a garden with tulips.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 24
column16: Page includes one photograph of a Black woman with studio lighting.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album,  page 25
column16: Page includes one photograph of a Black woman in a white dress holding a diploma.

column15: John L. Wallace Korean Conflict photo album, page 26
column16: Page includes one photograph of a Black soldier standing in the snow with his hands on his hips. Behind him is a sign with the text "Bayonnet . . . . . . assault."

column15: Valentine of a heart-shaped box and flowers
column16: Valentine created by Gibson Greeting Gards and signed "As ever, 'Dinky.'" Message on the front of the card reads: "A valentine message for the one I love." Interior message reads: "For you alone. There's the sweetest love in our hearts / That only the two of us share . . . / And, darling, wherever you go / My love will always be there ~ / For each little thought I have / Seems only to be of you, / Because I'm so much in love, dear . . . / and hope you love ME / that much too!"

column15: Valentine of a heart-shaped box and flowers, front
column16: Message reads: "A valentine message for the one I love."

column15: Valentine of a heart-shaped box and flowers, interior
column16: Printed text reads: "For you alone. There's the sweetest love in our hearts / That only the two of us share . . . / And, darling, wherever you go / My love will always be there ~ / For each little thought I have / Seems only to be of you, / Because I'm so much in love, dear . . . / and hope you love ME / that much too!" Signed "As ever, 'Dinky.'"

column15: Valentine of a heart-shaped box and flowers, back
column16: Text reads: "A Gibson Card / Gibson, Cinti, U.S.A. / 35V86272"

column15: Howard University library circulation card
column16: Blank circulation card with fields for entering the title, call number, due date, etc. of a book.

column15: Milbank Agricultural building postcard
column16: Postcard depicts the Milbank Agricultural building at the Tuskegee Institute in Alabama. The building is made of red brick and includes a porte cochere. The card is sent from Tommy in Alabama to Sgt. John L. Wallace in Michigan. It shares that the sender is fine and that Sgt. Wallace should get in touch with family.

column15: Milbank Agricultural building postcard, recto
column16: Postcard depicts the Milbank Agricultural building at the Tuskegee Institute in Alabama. The building is made of red brick and includes a porte cochere.

column15: Milbank Agricultural building postcard, verso
column16: Message reads: "Dr. Jr., I am having a fine time. Love Tommy. Write Uncle Elmo and Essie. 310 Washington Ave. Tuskegee Ist., Ala. Recepient address: Sgt. John L. Wallace Jr., Co "C" 171st M.P. BN, Fort Custer, Michigan."

column15: Junior Olympic Games contestant patch, 1948
column16: Patch features the acronym "WJW" and a figure with upraised hands holding a laurel wreath.

column15: Kansas City Missouri rodeo patch
column16: Circular green and white patch featuring an image of bronc riding, Some additional coloring is present.

column15: Invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball
column16: A pamphlet invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball taking place on April 17, 1959 in the National Guard Armory in Washington D.C.

column15: Invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball, cover
column16: Cover of a pamphlet invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball taking place on April 17, 1959 in the National Guard Armory in Washington D.C. A shriner crescent and scimitar are depicted in red.

column15: Invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball, interior
column16: The inner pages of a pamphlet invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball taking place on April 17, 1959 in the National Guard Armory in Washington D.C. The names of committee members and the invitation text are present

column15: Invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball, insert
column16: Insert for a pamphlet invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball taking place on April 17, 1959 in the National Guard Armory in Washington D.C. The insert has contact information for tickets and table reservations.

column15: Invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball, back cover
column16: Back cover of a pamphlet invitation to Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol's spring ball taking place on April 17, 1959 in the National Guard Armory in Washington D.C. Listed are the officers of the Mecca Temple No. 10 Patrol.

column15: Guest ticket to the Fifth Army Basketball Tournament
column16: Captain John L. Wallace of the "171st M.P.  Bn. Co. C" is listed as the guest. The tournament took place in Fort Riley, Kansas.

column15: District of Columbia National Guard card for John L. Wallace
column16: The card includes Wallace's name, signature, serial number, company, and unit commander (Robert S. Williams). Wallace's full name is given as John Lamond Wallace and his company is listed as "Co C 171st M.P. Bn DCNG." The card was issued on July 19, 1948. It notes that the holder is charged "with uniform and courteous military bearing and action."

column15: Camp McCoy NCO Mess membership card
column16: A membership card for non-commissioned officers training at Camp McCoy. The card entitles its holder to all membership privileges of the Camp McCoy NCO Mess.

column15: Camp McCoy NCO Mess membership card, front
column16: The front of the membership card includes Wallace's signature and states that he is entitled to all membership privileges. Also present is the signature of the President (Msgt. Leslie E.).

column15: Camp McCoy NCO Mess membership card, back
column16: The back of the membership card includes blank lines for September through August.

column15: Soldier's permanent pass
column16: A class "A" pass allowing unrestricted travel for the holder, John L. Wallace.

column15: Soldier's permanent pass, front
column16: A class "A" pass allowing unrestricted travel for the holder, John L. Wallace.

column15: Soldier's permanent pass, back
column16: A class "A" pass allowing unrestricted travel for the holder, John L. Wallace. The back includes instructions to follow for the pass to be valid.
